posts.text: Most female founders are the most powerful asset in their business and the least visible.  Today I am on site at Listerâ€™s Crisps directing founder BTS and brand story content. Women Donâ€™t Need Empowering. They Need the Truth.   When veteran founder Nichola Quail says women need to â€œget out of their own way,â€ she is not asking for permission from the empowerment industry. She is calling it out. In this punchy conversation on The Chief Uncensored, host Paul Essery digs into why so few solo female founders are seizing the AI moment, even when the tools are cheap, accessible, and in everyoneâ€™s hands.   Quail has built a global market research business by backing overlooked challenger brands and pairing them with top-tier independent researchers who usually sit far out of reach of early-stage budgets. Her message to female entrepreneurs is simple and uncomfortable: the funding gap is real, the bias is real, but opting out of the game guarantees you lose.   Bottom line: Stop waiting to be empowered; pick a lane, learn your numbers, use AI as a toolâ€”not a crutchâ€”and step into the rooms where decisions get made. Georgia Grace Edwards learned that the hard way while working as a glacier guide in Alaska â€” spending 8â€“12 hours a day on ice, stripping off layers in freezing temperatures just to use the bathroom, sometimes staying cold for hours afterward. At one point, she started dehydrating herself just to avoid it. What shocked her later wasnâ€™t the experience itself.  It was learning how normal it was. â€œWomen Supporting Womenâ€ is a phrase Iâ€™ve lived inside of for most of my career. And yet, the more time I spend with founders, investors, and operators, the more I feel the gap between support and power. The biggest fallacy is selling stories, not economics. The biggest reset we need is less optics, more transfer.  â€œMany iconic female founders fall into two camps: those who built companies before todayâ€™s complex digital economy, and those with deep privilegeâ€”family wealth, elite networks or both. Their stories inspire, but they arenâ€™t replicable. And because events continually platform the same figures, they often dominate the narrative.â€  â€œAnd when women founders do not talk about negative outcomesâ€”losing money in the exit process or calling a deal a strategic partnership when it's an "acquire-hire" dealâ€”the downside is nobody can really get lessons learned and do better.â€   My latest Forbes article explores this further.  https://lnkd.in/ea5qY8kE

One thing Iâ€™ve been thinking about a lot is how female founders talk about themselves.  Iâ€™ve noticed that some women will describe themselves as â€œnot business peopleâ€ or â€œclueless at businessâ€.  What Iâ€™ve learned is that this framing isnâ€™t neutral. Over time, it shapes who feels entitled to decide, to lead, and to take up space.  Research from King's College London  suggests women are more likely to underestimate their competence and over-emphasise gaps in their knowledge.  Meanwhile, many male founders learn in public while projecting certainty.  Neither approach guarantees success, but one gives you permission to act like a founder before you feel ready.  I donâ€™t think confidence needs to be loud (although if you want to be loud, you should). But I do think it needs to exist. Curious to hear experiences from other #femalefounders #womeninbusiness #entrepreneurship.

What a treat to see investors squirm for a change.   On Wednesday I spent the day at Google with an incredible community of women at Female Founders Raise, bringing founders and investors together through Female Founders Rise (huge thanks to Emmie Faust and Dan Bowyer).  One of the standout moments?   Turning the tables...and having investors pitch to founders.  It was refreshing, slightly uncomfortable (for them!), and genuinely insightful.   My biggest takeaways:  1. Investors invest in people: if you don't have traction through numbers you need traction through founder passion  2. Investment partnerships are like a marriage: don't get into bed with anyone you don't want to wake up next to with a hangover   3. $3.3 billion vs $1.1 million.  That's the funding gap between male and female founders in the GCC last quarter.  For every $1 that went to women, men received $3,000.  We talk about talent shortages. The best  relationships between a female founder and an advisor isn't one-directional. They are partnerships built on mutual value.  Many founders approach advisors, focusing only on what they need. But when you shift the framing to collaboration, the dynamic changes.   When a founder offers value in return, they establish themselves as a peer. That is the foundation for a relationship that deepens over time rather than fading after a few transactional exchanges.
